utterances: In the dark.
All right, Mary.
Thanks very much for the call.
A lot of lessons learned there.

Mike Turnbull, if if you do mess up and find yourself in this situation, and as I understand it, as soon as the water rises up high enough to hit your muffler, your car is going to stall out pretty quickly thereafter -what should you do?
Obama gives you the impression of being a tad detached.
And a lot of people just hate Hillary.
And John Edwards is warm and he connects with people as individuals.
Well, I think that, first of all, a car will float for approximately 45 seconds, so you do have some time.

And usually the batteries will keep providing power so that you can roll the windows down, because the first thing we need to do is try to get out of the vehicle, whether it's getting on top of it or, if it is going to start to roll, get away from the vehicle.
So if possible, if the car does settle and it feels fairly stable, get on the top of the car.
Get to the highest point.
That's our instinct, and that is a good way to do it.

And stay on the upstream side of the car, because if you - if you're thinking about it, if you're on the downstream side, what that's going to tend to do with that current pushing it, it's going to cause that car to roll easier.
Right.
So that is your lifeline.
If you're standing on top of that car and - stay there if you can if the car is going to be stable.
If it is going to roll, get away from it.
Get as far away as you can.
And we teach a swimming position, which is your feet downstream and do basically backstrokes.
That's to keep your feet from going down and catching on - remember, I said the stuff that's underneath the water that you can't see.
So - and then, if you - it is safe, turn over and swim aggressively, try to get to shore.
Okay.
So you do have some time once that car starts to move.
Let's get one last call in.
We just have a minute left.
Howard is with us from San Antonio.
Good afternoon.
Thank you for Rescue 3.
They trained me late in my career.
Early in my career, over 30 years ago, we did a - for a summer I worked with this particular fire department, we pulled 14 dead bodies from the river.
Oh my gosh.
And they were all sports (unintelligible) people on raft trips.
And thank you, Rescue 3, for your education.
I got it late in my career and never had to use it after that.
Thank God.
Thank you very much.
Howard...
Thank you.
Howard, thank you very much for the phone call and...
All right.
...and we've heard some situations that worked out, obviously some situations that didn't.
Mike Turnbull, thanks very much for the advice.
Neal, thank you for having me on.
Mike Turnbull, president of Rescue 3 International - as we heard, trainers of - for first responders in floodwater and rope rescue techniques, with us from Sacramento, California.
This is NEWS AND NOTES.
I'm Ed Gordon.
On today's Roundtable, scholars examine why some Latinos have a poor view of blacks, and Halliburton loses their exclusive lock.
Joining us today to discuss these topics and more, from our NPR headquarters in Washington, D.C., economist and author Julianne Malveaux.
She's president and CEO of Last Word Productions.
And from our New York bureau, Walter Fields, CEO and publisher of the NorthStarNetwork.com.
Also there, Pedro Noguera, professor of education at New York University.
All right, folks, before we get into those topics, I wanted to briefly -Walter, let me start with you - talk about what we heard from Russell Simmons, and I know you know Russell personally, as well.

The impassioned move that Russell has taken on for social change is interesting, also to look at where the hip-hop community is, because I do think, as I tried to get him to address, that they're stuck in the middle.

The idea of wanting social change, wanting to be a movement for that, but also falling back on some of misogynistic and also materialistic views of that, if we use it as a collective, a monolith, if you will.
I think you're right, and I think their intent is honorable.
I think the problem that they're having is that they have yet to own up to some of the negativity within their community.

I mean, I think it's important for them to take this step in terms of being more politicized, but they have to address issues of how they treat women, how they record their music, the lyrics they use.
And it's not a matter of policing, I think it's an accountability measure.

Because yes, art certainly has certain boundaries and we can accept the fact that artists should have some license to express themselves, and we certainly want to respect everyone's First Amendment rights; but if you're going to start talking about creating a political movement, I think you have to have a set of values that everyone agrees to in order to move forward.
I think there are some artists who are clearly responsible in the type of language they use.

There are others that are clearly not, and I think if they are really going to create a mass movement, they've got to address the issue of what are the bottom-line values that we want to rally around in order to make an impact, and really see the lives of the people that we care about improved.

And, Pedro, what I loved about Russell's answer, and believe me we've had many discussions publicly and privately about this, very heated sometimes, but the idea that - he did bring up an interesting point, and that is perhaps we're holding the hip-hop community to more accountability than we do others, including the government.
I thought his answer was interesting about the country being more gangster than those in the hip-hop community.
Well, I think that's a clever response, but it doesn't, I think, eliminate the question of what is their responsibility as artists to the community that they attempt to represent.
I think if we look to hip-hip artists for leadership in any kind of movement, we're in serious trouble.
Most of those artists are simply businessmen.
They will do whatever it takes to sell their music, including exploit all kinds of people.
